Award.AwardTitle: CCRI: ENS: Enhancement of Trust-Hub, a Web-based Portal to support the Cybersecurity Research Community

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: Concerns about electronic hardware and supply chain security have received a tremendous amount of attention over the past decade or so. Although researchers have offered solutions and security mechanisms to mitigate the issues, they do not still evaluate their effectiveness in a systematic manner. Some research is still being carried out in an ad-hoc fashion where the published results rely on figures of merit that limit objective cross-field comparisons. However, this has become vital as system-on-chips (SoCs) become pervasive in virtually every application (mobile, internet of things (IoT), and critical systems). This project aims to build platforms to validate benchmarks, develop tools and metrics to validate SoC security, and create a web-portal to disseminate and promote research and development in securing electronics devices and systems. The intellectual merits of this project include development of (i) a comprehensive SoC vulnerability database, (ii) a comprehensive set of metrics based on the vulnerability database, (iii) SoC security validation tool suite, and (iv) SoC benchmarking. This project leads a community-wide framework, called the Trust-Hub, toward stronger assurances in SoCs, computational platforms, and the electronics supply chain. Based on the demonstrated success of information sharing, Trust-Hub will serve as an important web-based repository for benchmarks, tools, databases, platforms, evaluation software, source codes, and much more.<br/><br/>The results will interest major semiconductor companies, US government agencies and university researchers worldwide. The broader impacts include benefits to the society by building secure and trustworthy electronic devices and systems for healthcare, defense, military, space, finance, transportation, automotive and other critical applications. The scientific results will be presented to the hardware and electronics security community, and to semiconductor companies and government agencies. Students will use the benchmarks and tools in the annual competitions. Finally, this project will support development of a workforce who understand the much-needed protection of electronics supply chain and intellectual property (IP).<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, the PIs continued the development of an information hub called Trust-Hub (www.trust-hub.org) with a focus on hardware security and trust. It serves as a central web-based repository for sharing resources, tutorials, courses, benchmarks, source codes, tools, hardware testing platforms, and other information that accelerates research and development in the field of hardware security.

Over the past several years, the Trust-Hub community has emphasized IP level security and trust (hardware Trojans, obfuscation, piracy, counterfeit, etc.). However, with increasing attention on system-on-chip (SoC) and heterogeneous architecture security, the community has felt a lack of resources, including vulnerability databases, tools, and metrics.

We believe Trust-Hub has played a major role in the rapid growth of the hardware security and trust community. Especially as new security primitives, attacks, and countermeasures emerge at the SoC level, the Trust-Hub team expanded the scope of the initial project to engage the larger hardware security community.

To achieve this, the accomplished goals of this Trust-Hub ENS are:

Task 1: Physical SoC security tools, metrics, and classifications: This task focuses on developing tools, metrics, classifications, benchmarks/datasets related to physical attacks (probing, fault injection, circuit edit, side-channel analysis, reverse engineering). These will enable community researchers to evaluate vulnerabilities in SoC designs/layouts and their associated countermeasures.

Task 2: AI Security benchmarking, Metrics: This task focuses on developing fundamental automated tools to discover vulnerabilities and defenses for emerging AI-based methodologies in hardware security. Community researchers can utilize these tools for IP protection, security, and privacy, along with creating metrics and benchmarks for AI-based methodologies' trustworthiness.

Task 3: CAD (Computer-Aided Design) Tools, SoC Benchmarking: This task focuses on developing automated tools to detect vulnerabilities and benchmark SoCs with multiple vulnerabilities. Community researchers can evaluate these vulnerabilities effectively.

Task 4: CSAW Metrics: This task focuses on various hardware-based challenges (ESC, Logic Locking, Hardware AI vs AI), competitions, benchmarks, and metrics.

Trust-Hub enjoys significant community support. Therefore, we will collaborate closely with many members to develop these tools and metrics collaboratively. Members greatly benefit from Trust-Hub as it provides an excellent platform for sharing and publicizing their tools.
